I just did this with about a 76% yield. That's even after I had a foaming accident that lost several grams of product.
I used a soxhlet extractor with molecular sieves to get the water out of the alcohol as it was refluxing.
I used 40g (~0.292 mol) of PABA and about 250 ml ethanol, 15 cc of 98% sulfuric, and let it reflux for 2 hours.
Then I added it to a saturated solution of sodium bicarbonate. I got too happy with the pipette, though, and that's when it foamed over.
Washed it a couple times with distilled water, vacuum filtered it, and let it dry for 2 days in a sunny window.
When it was nice and dry, it yielded 36.53g (~0.221 mol)

Great video- however as a quick note, you switched the assignment of hydrophilic and hydrophobic ends for benzocaine- a methyl group is hardly hydrophilic and would in fact be "lipophilic", while the amine on the benzene ring can engage in hydrogen bonding with water, making it the hydrophobic end.

You did actually address the reduction in concentration of the products, using 98% sulphuric acid means that any water formed is locked up by the reaction: H2SO4+H2O-<del>>H3O(+) + HSO4(</del>) meaning it's unable to reaction with the ester like H2O does, that's the main catalytic property of the sulphuric acid as opposed to other strong acids. HCl works, but you get around 30% of the yield that you do with H2SO4.

Also you can use a Dean Stark or a Soxhlet extractor packed with 4Ams (or 3Ams) to remove the water from the azeotrope and return anhyd solvent to push the equilibrium. However the rxn time will be increased as sieves aren't fast at absorbing H2O.

Hey dude some suggestions on the neutralization of your acid to increase yield:
1) add the solid NaHCO3 thereby not adding any water to the rxn mix
or
2) if you only have the aqueous base, add the acidic solution to the base while stirring. This way the acid is neutralized and hydrolysis of the product does not occur. If you add the bicarb to the acid slowly to not foam over, the pH is still well below 7 to conduct the acid catalyzed hydrolysis when you are adding water.

One thing to be aware of with molecular sieves is that they are slightly basic. This means that (in this type of reaction) if you add conc. sulfuric acid to them, they will be fairly likely to decompose to an amorphous sludge. They should still work (perhaps to a lesser degree, but i'm not certain) but it would involve a few additional filtration steps to remove the sieve powder.
On a related note, don't do what I did and try to store your beautiful clean glacial acetic acid over 4A sieves.
